item.title: Bases for Topologies
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. To specify a topology on $X$, one needs to give a complete description of the open sets. In practice, one only specifies a smaller collection (that nonetheless pins down all open sets). There are two levels of subcollections that generate a topology. If $\mc{T}$ is a given topology on $X$, what subcollections $\mc{B}\subseteq\mc{T}$ completely specify $\mc{T}$? What kinds of collections $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ can specify some topology $\mc{T}$ on $X$?

This is indeed the case for finite $p$-groups, which we now show. Throughout, let $G$ be a non-trivial finite $p$-group. Lemma. item.title: The Class Equation
item.description: Statement & Proof A group $G$ acting on a finite set $S$ naturally partitions $S$ into its orbits $S=\bigsqcup_{i\in I}Gs_i$, which can either be trivial or non-trivial. The trivial ones are singletons $\l\{s_i\r\}$ for which each $s_i$ is fixed by all $g\in G$. We call those the fixed points of the action, denoted $Z\coloneqq\l\{s\in S\st gs=s\textrm{ for all }g\in G\r\}$. If some structure is known about the non-trivial orbits, then this partition gives us information on the number $\l|Z\r|$ of fixed points of this action.

item.title: Lagrange’s Theorem
item.description: Statement & Proof This classical result is fundamental in finite group theory, since it places limitations on the size a subgroup of a finite group can have. For a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ of $G$, let $[G:H]\coloneqq\l|G/H\r|$ be the index of $H$ in $G$. Theorem (Lagrange). Let $G$ be a finite group. For every subgroup $H\substructeq G$, we have $\l|G\r|=[G:H]\cdot\l|H\r|$. In particular, $\l|H\r|$ divides $\l|G\r|$. Proof. Click to expand... Consider the natural left-multiplication

item.title: Cayley’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Whenever one encounters a type of mathematical object, one should ask if there is an associated ‘representation theorem’. Such a theorem for groups is as follows. Theorem (Cayley). Every group $G$ is a subgroup of a symmetry group. Proof. Click to expand... We show that the left-multiplication action $\phi:G\to\Aut G$ is faithful, for then $G\substructeq\Aut G$. Indeed, if $\phi(g_1)=\phi(g_2)$, then we have $\phi(g_1)g=\phi(g_2)g$ for all $g\in G$. That is, we have $g_1g=g_2g$, so $g_1=g_2$ as desired.

item.title: Filter
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $P$ be a poset. A filter on $P$ is a subset $\em\neq F\subseteq P$ such that (Upward-closure). If $p\in F$ and $q\geq p$, then $q\in F$. (Downward-directed). If $p_1,p_2\in F$, then there exists $q\in F$ with $q\leq p_1,p_2$.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Oftentimes, we wish to regard two objects as ‘being the same’ (for instance, two sets are ‘the same’ if they have the same cardinality), despite them not being equal. The concept of an equivalence relation can be thought of as a generalization of equality. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a (binary) relation $E\subseteq X^2$ subject to the following conditions. (Reflexive). For all $x\in X$, we have $(x,x)\in E$.

item.title: Quotient Set
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix an equivalence relation $E$ on $X$. We would like to construct some set $X/E$ and some function $\pi:X\to X/E$ in which ‘$E$ becomes equality’ through $\pi$. Moreover, this construction needs to be universal, in the precise sense that: For any set $Z$ and any function $f:X\to Z$ such that $xEy$ implies $f(x)=f(y)$ for all $x,y\in X$, there is a unique function $f’:X/E\to Z$ such that $f=f’\circ\pi$.

item.title: Quotient Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix an equivalence relation on a group $G$ and consider the quotient set $G/\!\sim$. Since $\sim$ has, a priori, nothing to do with the group structure of $G$, we cannot expect $G/\!\sim$ to carry a natural group structure. Instead, we need to consider a congruence $\sim$ on $G$, which (in the category $\catgrp$) is an equivalence relation $\sim$ such that $g_1\sim g_2$ and $h_1\sim h_2$ implies $g_1h_1\sim g_2h_2$.

item.title: Normal Subgroup
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a group $G$ and consider the category $\cat{B}G$ defined by $G$ (consisting of a single object $\ast$, and morphisms $\Hom(\ast,\ast)=G$). What are the congruences in $\cat{B}G$? Definition. A subgroup $N\substructeq G$ is said to be normal if it is invariant under the conjugation action of $G$; i.e., if $gN=Ng$ for all $g\in G$. In this case, we write $N\nsubgrpeq G$, and $N\nsubgrp G$ if it is proper.

item.title: Kernel (Group Theory)
item.description: Motivation & Definition A special property of the category of groups is the existence of a zero object; namely, the trivial group $\l\{0\r\}$; by definition, we have a morphism $0:G\to\l\{0\r\}\to H$ for each pair $G,H$ of groups. Now, for an arbitrary homomorphism $f:G\to H$, we would like to find some group $K$ that ‘forces’ $f$ to ‘equalize’ with $0$ in a universal way. This can be done in two $-$ dual $-$ ways, called the kernel and cokernel of $f$.

item.title: Subgroup
item.description: Definition and Generation A standard method of studying an object $-$ in this case, a group $G$ $-$ is to analyze other groups that ‘sit inside’ $G$. This is formalized in the following Definition. Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup of $G$ is a subset $H\subseteq G$ equipped with a group structure making the inclusion $H\into G$ a group homomorphism. We write $H\substructeq G$ to indicate that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: To study the quotient objects in a category, we must first understand the congruence relations in said category. For $\catring$, these are in correspondence with ideals. Definition. Let $R$ be a ring. A (left) ideal in $R$ is a subgroup $(\mf{a},+)\substructeq R$ such that $r\mf{a}\subseteq\mf{a}$ for all $r\in R$. Similarly for right ideals and two-sided ideals.

Indeed, $\End G$ is itself Abelian $-$ but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense of: Definition. We give some group-theoretic frameworks for which such combinatorics can be applied to. Such methods can become incredibly sophisticated; for instance, the classification of finite simple groups is one of the major achievements of mathematics. We only touch on the very very basics here.

item.title: Order
item.description: Definition. Let $G$ be a group. An element $x\in G$ is has finite order if we have $x^n=e$ for some $n>0$; the least such $n$ is the order of $x$, denoted $\ord x$. Otherwise, set $\ord x\coloneqq\infty$, and say that $x$ has infinite order. Remark. More abstractly, for a fixed $x\in G$, consider the map $\phi_x:\Z\to G$ induced uniquely by sending $1\mapsto x$, and set $\ord x\coloneqq\l|\im\phi_x\r|$. If $\ker\phi_x=n\Z$ for some $n>0$, then $\im\phi_x\iso\Z/n\Z$ has cardinality $n$.

Depending on the order $n\coloneqq\ord x$ of $x$, $G$ takes on the following forms. If $1\leq n<\infty$, then $\ker\phi=n\Z$ and hence $G\iso\Z/n\Z$.

A (covariant) functor $F:C\to D$ is the data of two functions: An object function, assigning some $Fc\in D$ to each $c\in C$, and A morphism function, assigning some $Ff:Fc\to Fc’$ to each $f:c\to c’$, interacting in such a way that $$\begin{equation} F1_c=1_{Fc}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textrm{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ F(f\circ g)=Ff\circ Fg \end{equation}$$ for all objects $c\in C$ and morphisms $f,g\in C$ whenever $f\circ g\in C$ is defined.

item.title: Group Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition Groups capture $-$ abstractly $-$ the notion of a symmetry. But symmetries are also present in concrete objects, with different kinds of objects preserving different kinds of structure. The concept of a group action connects the two. Definition. Let $G$ be a group and fix a category $C$. A $G$-action is a functor $\cat{B}G\to C$, which specifies an object $X\in C$ and a homomorphism $\phi:G\to\Aut X$. Thus a group action is specified by the data of a tuple $\tpl{X,\phi}$, which we usually write as $\phi:G\act X$.

item.title: Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a group was invented to capture the abstract properties of symmetries (i.e. transformations that preserve internal ‘structure’) of geometrical objects. These transformations must be composable in the following coherent way. Definition. A group is a tuple $\tpl{G,\cdot,e,\iota}$ consisting of underlying set $G$, a distinguished element $e\in G$ called the identity, and operations $\cdot:G\times G\to G$ and $\iota:G\to G$, subject to the following conditions. (Associativity). For all $g,h,k\in G$, we have $g\cdot(h\cdot k)=(g\cdot h)\cdot k$.

item.title: Metric Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Abstracting away the basic properties of Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality, we make the following Definition. A metric on a set $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$. (Symmetry.) For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=d(y,x)$. ($\Delta$-inequality). For all $x,y,z\in X$, we have $d(x,z)\leq d(x,y)+d(y,z)$. If $d$ is a metric on $X$, we call the pair $\tpl{X,d}$ a metric space.

item.title: Topological Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘closeness’ between two points without necessarily referring to a specific metric, but rather, via certain subsets of $X$ called open sets. One can think of these open sets as specifying ‘proximity’ without necessarily satisfying the triangle inequality. The following definition is motivated by some properties $^\dagger$ of open sets generated by a metric $d$ on $X$, which we now axiomatize.
